summary: Internal email correspondence among U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (SDNY) staff discussing draft press guidance for the upcoming trial of Ghislaine Maxwell. The guidance outlines procedures for witness pseudonyms, media access, and trial logistics.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant charged with conspiring with Jeffrey Epstein to entice minors to travel to engage in criminal sexual activity. Her trial is the subject of the press guidance.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the individual with whom Ghislaine Maxwell conspired to commit the alleged crimes involving minors.

persons.name: Alison Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge over the case U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell, mentioned as conducting the final pretrial conference.

persons.name: Margolin, James
persons.context: Listed as a recipient/copied on internal email discussions regarding the press guidance.

persons.name: Echenberg, Janis
persons.context: SDNY staff member providing feedback on the draft press guidance, suggesting inclusion of court orders and requesting to be copied on distributions.

connections.description: Maxwell is charged with conspiring with Epstein to entice minors to travel to engage in criminal sexual activity.
Judge Alison Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's criminal case.

events.title: Final Pretrial Conference in U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: Scheduled final pretrial conference before Judge Alison Nathan at the Thurgood Marshall U.S. Courthouse.

events.title: Media Account Access Deadline
events.description: Deadline for media to establish accounts to access government exhibits via the SDNY file share.

locations: Courtroom 318, 40 Foley Square (Thurgood Marshall U.S. Courthouse)
Overflow Courtrooms 110, 506, 905, and 906 of the Thurgood Marshall U.S. Courthouse
keyFacts: The government anticipated that several witnesses in the Ghislaine Maxwell trial would testify using pseudonyms or first names, a measure granted by the court to protect victim-witnesses describing sensitive and explicit illegal sexual abuse.
The press guidance was being prepared to manage high media demand and ensure efficient communication, highlighting the high-profile nature of the trial.
Government exhibits for the trial were to be provided exclusively through a secure SDNY file share (USAFx), requiring media to establish accounts for access.

The document reveals internal SDNY coordination and caution regarding commitments to daily press guidance on witnesses, due to the difficulty of reliably knowing the next day's testifying witnesses in advance.
The case is formally titled U.S. v. Ghislaine Maxwell, charging her with conspiring with Jeffrey Epstein to entice minors to travel to engage in criminal sexual activity.
